message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about the behavior of lightbulbs when they are turned on. When a lightbulb is powered on, it produces light by converting electrical energy into thermal energy. This means that the inside of the lightbulb becomes hot. If cold water is suddenly applied to the hot inside of the lightbulb, it can cause the glass to crack or shatter due to the rapid change in temperature. Option (A) is incorrect because electricity and water can conduct or attract each other, not repel. Option (B) is also incorrect because the inside of the lightbulb becomes hot when it is powered on. Option (C) is incorrect because the water does not start to boil, but rather the glass of the lightbulb can burst due to the sudden temperature change.

This question requires basic knowledge about the properties of lightbulbs and the effects of rapid temperature changes. When a lightbulb is powered on, the inside of the bulb heats up due to the electrical current flowing through it. If cold water is suddenly poured over the hot bulb, the rapid temperature change can cause the bulb to burst. Option (A) is incorrect because electricity and water do not repel each other, but the combination of electricity and water can be dangerous. Option (B) is incorrect because the inside of the lightbulb becomes hot when it is powered on. Option (C) is incorrect because the water does not boil when it comes into contact with the hot bulb.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the properties of lightbulbs and the effects of temperature. When a lightbulb is powered on, the filament inside the bulb heats up and produces light. This means that the inside of the lightbulb becomes hot. When cold water is poured onto the hot bulb, the rapid change in temperature causes the glass to shatter. Option (A) is incorrect because electricity and water do not repel each other, but rather they can conduct electricity, which can be dangerous. Option (B) is also incorrect because the inside of the lightbulb becomes hot when it is powered on. Option (C) is untrue because the water does not have enough time to boil when it comes into contact with the hot bulb.

This question requires basic knowledge about the behavior of lightbulbs when they are turned on. When a lightbulb is powered on, the inside filament heats up, producing light. This means that the inside of the lightbulb is hot. If cold water is poured over a hot surface, such as the inside of a lightbulb, it can cause the glass to crack or burst due to thermal shock. Option (A) is incorrect because electricity and water can conduct electricity and pose a safety hazard, but they do not repel each other. Option (B) is incorrect because the inside of a powered on lightbulb is actually hot, not cool. Option (C) is incorrect because pouring cold water on a hot surface does not cause the water to immediately boil.

Option (B) is incorrect because the inside of the lightbulb is actually hot, not cool. Option (C) is incorrect because the water does not have a chance to boil before the lightbulb bursts.
